title: (x) "True Confessions" serial nameplate - hand lettered {Yves}
content:
Help needed in identifying the font used for ‘True Confessions’ [http://www.philsp.com/data/images/t/true\_confessions\_193311.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20060513005132/http:/www.philsp.com/data/images/t/true_confessions_193311.jpg)

Thank you.
author: whatisit

comments.content: Now _that_ is almost certainly hand drawn. In those days it made much more sense to have a lettering artist custom design the nameplate of your magazine, as well as type for advertisements and such. Furthermore there was no way on earth they could have done the overlapping T and C and the negative leading with type.

Okay, but how’bout a font or two close to that style.

(toke…toke…searching myfonts.com…mmmm…)

[Conserif](http://web.archive.org/web/20060513005132/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/blhd/conserif-cw/) is sorta-kinda close.

[1971 more fonts like that](http://web.archive.org/web/20060513005132/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/blhd/conserif-cw/morelikethis.html)

[Another list of slabbies](http://web.archive.org/web/20060513005132/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/hancock-rr/morelikethis.html)

(…toke…mmmm…)

_no way on earth they could have done the overlapping T and C and the negative leading with type._

And the larger point size in metal would have much heavier strokes. The T you’d have to chop and channel with a welder to get the length.

j a m e s
